awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nanofluidics Enabled Attenuation of Dynamic Impacts and Stress Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
Dynamic impacts can cause stress waves within solid materials, resulting in damage to infrastructure, personnel, or devices.  However, current approaches to mitigate stress waves are inadequate in that they rely on energy absorption associated with unrecoverable buckling and/or plastic deformation of materials and structures. Moreover, the time required to deform these materials is typically much longer than the time needed for dynamic impacts and stress waves to propagate through these protection materials.  Nanofluidics, in which the liquid is forced into nanoscale channels by an external pressure or stress, is expected to attenuate stress waves and offers a entirely new paradigm for the design of protection materials and structures. The overarching goal of this project is to investigate and understand nanofluidics-enabled mitigation of dynamic impacts and stress waves with particular focus on nanofluidics in three-dimensional nanoporous networks. This collaborative project will also provide a broad impact on education including professional trainings to both graduate and undergraduate students, and on outreach including inspiring interactions with local high schools.

The objective of this collaborative project is to systematically investigate the science of nanofluidics in non-wetting liquid-solid nanoporous composite materials, and to explore its underlying protection mechanism for mitigating dynamic impacts and stress waves.  To this end, the proposed research will focus on three tasks: (i) to investigate and unveil the science of nanofluidics in non-wetting liquid-solid nanoporous structures under a high speed loading using atomistic simulations, (ii) to develop a theoretical model of nanofluidic energy capture mechanism to quantify nanofluidic responses to dynamic impacts and stress waves, and (iii) to design and carry out verification experiments at high strain rates by employing non-wetting liquid-solid nanoporous materials platforms. The nanofluidic energy capture mechanism will refresh existing design strategies of protection materials and structures subjected to stress waves, thereby revolutionizing both fundamental nanofluidics and application technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Attenuation of mechanical impacts and stress waves has been pursued to protect personnel and important infrastructures and devices and becomes increasingly desirable in recent years due to common occurrences of explosion and collision from civil infrastructure, industry to military. This collaborative project systematically investigated the science of nanofluidics in non-wetting liquid-solid nanoporous materials, and explore a novel protection mechanism for mitigating dynamic impacts and stress waves by understanding the intrusion and extrusion of liquid into hydrophobic nanopores. With the completion of this project,  we proposed a quantitative model to reveal the competition mechanism between liquid infiltration and nanopore buckling/collapse subjected to a quasi-static loading. The established theory has successfully addressed a long-standing fuzzy question in the study of liquid intrusion into porous structures, and offers a foundation for developing advanced porosity characterization technologies in materials science and chemical engineering. We systematically studied the outflow process of liquid water and electrolyte solutions out of hydrophobic nanopores decorated with the grafted silyl chains and reported a design strategy that enables to achieve a continuous and spontaneous liquid outflow from hydrophobic nanopores with high and stable efficiency by regulating the confinement of solid-liquid interactions with functionalized nanopores or/and liquids. We also proposed a completely novel mechanism of molecular cohesion and ion distribution mechanisms to uncover the effect of hydration radii of these alkaline ions and its competition with the size of the hydrophobic nanopores, extending the traditional confinements of hydrophobicity. These findings help explore design strategies of nanopore structures and liquid solutions for non-wetting liquid-nanopore material systems, unlocking a vast array of potential applications in the design of nanofluidics-enabled, reusable, sustainable functional materials, structures and devices. We investigated the outflow of confined water from a hydrophobic nanopore and found an unexpected solid-like outflow property that exhibits its strong similarity with that of mechanical deformation of solid metal nanowires subjected to a uniaxial tensile load from the initial continuous outflow response to the gradual break along with a formation of an apparent neck-like shape. We propose a solid-like mechanics scaling law of outflow deformation and strength that is incorporated with the solid-liquid interfacial energy and confinement pore size and temperature of the liquid and quantitatively characterized both elastic modulus and failure strength of confined water outflow. These results offers a facile route for probing mechanical and structural properties of nanoconfined liquid. We reported an electrical suppression approach to slow down the outflow of water confined in hydrophobic nanopores and lay a foundation of retarding the fast outflow of confined liquid in hydrophobic nanopores with electrical field, potentially useful for exploring electrically controllable nanofluidics-based functional devices and structures. These results have led to 9 peer- reviewed journal publications including PNAS, Matter and ACS Nano, and two of them were also featured in the inside front cover of the journal Nanoscale and the supplementary cover of ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces.

The PI and support PhD students have reported the results through ASME-IMCE conferences and several department seminars. One PhD has finished the PhD degree and now is a post-doc at the University of Pennsylvania. The other PhD student is expected to graduate in 2023 Spring. PhD students have been awarded Student Poster Travel Award for several times, the most informative poster by 2021 ASME-IMECE, and Haythornthwaite Foundation Student Travel Award. The PI was invited to write one journal perspective and one review journal article summarizing the progress in this field of relevance to this project has also awarded 2020 ASME Sia Nemat-Nasser Early Career Award. In addition, several undergraduates were involved, and one of them is co-authorized to the review paper with the equal contribution to the first author. This completion of this project helped the PI build connections with clinical doctor and for immediate applications in disease diagnose for human healthcare by exploring nanofluidics based biomedical devices. 

The research results of relevance were lectured in graduate-level class MAE 6070 The theory of Elasticity, and were also incorporated into a newly developed undergraduate student course: Mechanical Design and Manufacturing in Wearable Electronics (MAE4610), offered course by the PI.


Last Modified: 09/03/2022
Modified by: Baoxing Xu
